heading.title: The Ringed Planet...
heading.summary: A vast world coated with a streaking sea of hydrogen and helium gas surrounded by a thin ring of ice crystals. Saturn is named after the Roman god of farming and wealth since it has a rich and prominent ring system and its golden glow was reminiscent of wheat.

overview.point1: Saturn was first noted by the ancient Greeks who named it after their god of agriculture. Galileo was the first to observe it through telescope in the early 1600s.
overview.point2: It is named after the Roman god of agriculture, based on the Greeks' label.
overview.point3: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun at a distance of 886 million miles.

features.point1: Saturn is the second of the gas giants and the only gas giant to posess a prominent ring system. Its atmopshere is made up of hydrogen and helium, which appear as golden clouds on the surface.
features.point2: A day on Saturn lasts about 10 hours and 40 minutes and it takes Saturn 29 years to orbit the Sun. It orbits the Sun at a rate of 21,000 miles per hour.
features.point3: Saturn is approximately 10 times more massive than the Earth. It has a diameter of 72,367 miles and a circumference of 227,000 miles. If you factor in its ring system, Saturn is wide enough to span over 9 Earths.
features.point4: The atmopshere of saturn is comprised of hydrogen and helium gas which form streaks of brown, gold, and gray hues.
features.point5: Saturn has a massive hexagonal storm on its north pole, it is a tremendous hurricane capable of swallowing the entire Earth whole. Since Saturn tilts on it's axis, it has seasons which each last for 7 years.
features.point6: Saturn has over 80 moons. The largest moon, Titan is nearly as big as Mars and has a fairly dense atmopshere comprised of over 90% nitrogen.
features.point7: To see Saturn, look for a pale yellow star in the early dawn that hangs low over the southern horizon.

extras.point1: Saturn is the last of the planets that are visible to the naked eye.
extras.point2: Saturn is the least dense planet in the Solar System.
extras.point3: It is likely that more moons will be discovered orbiting Saturn.

images.img1: The upper atmopshere of Saturn as it appeared from the Cassini spacecraft in 2017.
images.img2: Saturn's hexagonal storm on its north pole.
images.img3: Saturn's largest moon, Titan, which has an atmopshere made of nitrogen.
